document.masterDocTitle: An annotated and illustrated checklist of the porcelain crabs of Panama (Decapoda: Anomura)

Previous records from Panama
. Haig (1968) ; Gore & Abele (1976) .

Distribution . East Pacific: Clipperton I., Mexico , Costa Rica , Panama (Coiba Is., Bahía Honda in Veraguas , Punta Mala, Taboga Is., Las Perlas Is.), Colombia , Ecuador (including Galápagos ) and Peru ( Haig 1968 ; Gore & Abele 1976 ; Gore 1982 ; Moscoso 2012 ; present study).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 54 .
Petrolisthes haigae Chace, 1962
: A–C, male (cl 5.5 mm, cw 5.3 mm) from Coiba Island, Panama (FLMNH UF 57714), dorsal (A), ventral (B) and frontal (C) views [photographs by AA].

FIGURE 55 .
Petrolisthes haigae Chace, 1962
: A, B, female (cl 5.4 mm, cw 5.3 mm) from Punta Mala, Panama (MZUSP 40071), dorsal (A) and ventral (B) views [photographs by AA].

FIGURE 56 .
Petrolisthes haigae Chace, 1962
: A, ovigerous female (cl 5.7 mm, cw 5.2 mm) from Coiba Island, Panama (FLMNH UF 57713), dorsal view; B, C, male (cl cw indet.) from Taboga Island, Panama (not deposited), dorsal (B) and ventral (C) views; D, ovigerous female (cl cw indet.) from the same locality (not deposited), ventral view; E, male (cl cw indet.) from the same locality (not deposited) [photographs by AA].

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks .
Petrolisthes haigae
was previously regarded as the probable eastern Pacific sister species of the amphi-Atlantic
P. marginatus Stimpson, 1859
(=
P. cessacii A. Milne-Edwards, 1878
), differing from the latter by the carapace front broader and rounded ( vs. narrower and oblong in
P. marginatus
); the median frontal lobe shorter and broader ( vs. more prominent and narrower in
P. marginatus
); and the P1 robust, with the lateral margin of the propodus rounded ( vs. slender, with the lateral margin of the propodus nearly straight in
P. marginatus
) ( Ferreira & Tavares 2017 ). However,
Hiller et al. (2006)
recovered a sister relationship of
P. haigae
with
P. hirtispinosus Lockington, 1878
, and not with
P. marginatus
.

The colour pattern of the Panamanian specimens of
P. haigae
is relatively homogeneous dorsally, however, presenting some variation on the ventral side ( Figs. 54–56 ). For instance, the colour of the ventral side of the P1 palms may vary from yellowish to intense pink-red ( Figs. 54B , 55B , 56C–E ). Noteworthy, the porcelain crab from Galápagos identified as
P. haigae
in the colour photograph in Hickman & Zimmerman (2000) is generally much darker and could represent at least a genetically isolated population.
